Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Deborah Ann Sunter of the University of California, Berkeley to conduct a research project, entitled "Economic and environmental comparison of residential combined heat and power systems in Japan," during the summer of 2012 at the University of Kitakyushu in Kitakyushu, Japan. The host scientist is Professor Weijun Gao.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is an analysis of the economic and environmental potentials of solar thermal micro combined heat and power (CHP) systems for the residential sector in Japan. Despite the significant economic merit of both the gas engine and fuel cell micro CHP residential systems when introduced in Japanese homes, the environmental potential for both systems was found to be disappointingly low. This research investigates uses of micro CHP systems using renewable energy sources, in this case solar thermanl energy, to more dramatically reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2008, Japan revealed ambitious goals to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to 60-80% the 1990 baseline level by the year 2050 [1]. In 2007, the GHG emissions were 12.2% greater than those in 1990 [2]. Then, in March 2011, Japan suffered a tremendous tragedy: earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis. All but 15 of the country’s 54 nuclear reactors were shut down [3]. To compensate for this loss in energy generation, dozens of fossil fuel plants were fired up, many of which had been idle for over a year [3]. Additionally, billions of dollars were spent on importing natural gas, coal and oil. It has been estimated that by 2013, GHG emissions will increase to 16% above the 1990 baseline level, moving Japan even further from their 2050 goal [3]. With the emission of greenhouse gases causing a myriad of environmental, health and political problems, low cost renewable energies are being aggressively sought. International collaboration in sustainable energy alternatives is essential to address this global problem.

 

In the summer of 2012, I participated in the EAPSI program in Japan. I had the pleasure of working with Professor Weijun Gao at the University of Kitakyushu, Japan. Professor Gao has done extensive research in distributed combined heat and power systems, in particular for the gas engine and fuel cell. I hoped to expand his research to include solar thermal systems, the topic of my doctorate research.  Together, we developed an energy proposal for the University of Kitakyushu that compared a 200 kW gas engine combined heat and power system to an equally sized solar thermal system. This would account for 20% of the energy portfolio for the University of Kitakyushu. Using commercially available solar thermal systems from Sopogy Inc. for the analysis, it was found that the solar thermal system was both more cost effective and environmentally friendly than the gas engine. The levelized cost of electricity was 5.7% less and the CO2 emissions were 5.2% less. The results were so promising that we presented them to FAIS (Foundation of the Advancement of Industry Science and Technology).

 

In addition, I had several other research opportunities while in Japan. I presented a novel design of a solar absorber tube at the Pacific Rim Energy and Sustainability Congress. I was able to assist a fellow graduate student in sizing a combined heat and power system for convenient stores in Thailand. I gave a lecture at the University of Kitakyushu on current and historic energy portfolios for the world, America, and California. I toured several environmentally sustainable systems: University of Kitakyushu distributed energy center and water treatment plant, the Kitakyushu Eco-Town and Smart Community, and an environmentally-recovered harbor near Moji-ku.

 

I feel truly blessed to have participated in the EAPSI program. I sincerely thank everyone who made this possible.

 

References:

  [1] Ren, H. and Gao, W. “Economic and Environmental Evaluation of Micro CHP Systems with Different Operating Modes for Residential Buildings in Japan.” Energy and Buildings AIP (2010), 853-861.

 [2] National Institute for Environmental Studies, National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Report of Japan, Ministry of the Environment, Japan, 2009.

 [3] Tabuchi, Hiroko. “Japan Quake is Causing Costly Shift to Fossil Fuels.” New York Times. New York Times, 19 August 2011. Web. 15 October 2011.
